cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding rebound tenderness is correct?

A. The absence of rebound tenderness rules out intra-abdominal injury.
B. Rebound tenderness is a specific sign found with a spleen injury.
C. It is often discovered when the patient is jarred or moved suddenly.
D. It should be assessed for by vigorously palpating the abdomen.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries
cards.back: It is often discovered when the patient is jarred or moved suddenly.

cards.front:
The mesentery is:

A. a layer of thick skeletal muscles that protects the abdominal organs.
B. a complex network of blood vessels that supply blood to the liver.
C. the point of attachment between the small and large intestines.
D. a membranous fold that attaches the intestines to the walls of the body.
See Anatomy and Physiology of the Abdomen
cards.back: a membranous fold that attaches the intestines to the walls of the body.

cards.front:
When documenting a call involving a female patient who was sexually assaulted, the EMT should:

A. avoid speculation and document only factual data.
B. include the results of the internal vaginal exam.
C. include a description of the suspected perpetrator.
D. theorize as to why the sexual assault occurred.
See Sexual Assault and Rape
cards.back: avoid speculation and document only factual data.

cards.front:
All of the following are hollow abdominal organs, except the:

A. ureters.
B. stomach.
C. spleen.
D. bladder.
See Anatomy and Physiology of the Abdomen

A sign of kidney damage after blunt trauma is:

A. hematemesis.
B. hematuria.
C. hematochezia.
D. hemoptysis.
See Emergency Medical Care of Genitourinary Injuries

Which of the following organs is at most risk for injury as the result of a pelvic fracture?

A. Liver or spleen
B. Urinary bladder
C. Fallopian tubes
D. Pancreas
See Injuries of the Genitourinary System

Early bruising following abdominal trauma often manifests as:

A. localized pain.
B. red areas of skin.
C. gross distention.
D. dark purple marks.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries

Which of the following organs would most likely bleed profusely when injured?

A. Intestine
B. Stomach
C. Bladder
D. Liver
See Abdominal Injuries

Because the depth of an open abdominal wound is often difficult to determine:

A. prompt transport to the hospital is essential.
B. vital signs should be monitored frequently.
C. the abdomen must be vigorously palpated.
D. the EMT must perform a thorough exam.
See Abdominal Injuries
cards.back: prompt transport to the hospital is essential.

cards.front:
Bruising to the right upper quadrant of the abdomen after blunt trauma is most suggestive of injury to the:

A. liver.
B. stomach.
C. kidney.
D. spleen.
See Anatomy and Physiology of the Abdomen

Accumulation of blood in the abdominal cavity will most likely cause:

A. diffuse bruising.
B. referred pain.
C. nausea or vomiting.
D. distention.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries

Peritonitis usually occurs when:

A. the vessels that supply the abdominal organs become inflamed.
B. solid abdominal organs bleed secondary to penetrating trauma.
C. bacteria or viruses invade the walls of the gastrointestinal tract.
D. hollow abdominal organs are damaged and spill their contents.
See Anatomy and Physiology of the Abdomen
cards.back: hollow abdominal organs are damaged and spill their contents.

cards.front:
The presence of tachycardia following a significant abdominal injury:

A. should be assumed to be a sign of shock.
B. indicates a state of decompensated shock.
C. is most commonly caused by severe pain.
D. is always accompanied by hypotension.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries
cards.back: should be assumed to be a sign of shock.

cards.front:
Contraction or tensing of the abdominal muscles to ease pain is called:

A. guarding.
B. flexing.
C. referring.
D. withdrawing.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries

Difficulty breathing and a sunken appearance of the anterior abdominal wall is most indicative of a ruptured:

A. aorta.
B. spleen.
C. diaphragm.
D. stomach.
See Emergency Medical Care of Abdominal Injuries

During your assessment of a patient who experienced blunt trauma to the abdomen, you notice bruising around the umbilicus. This is a sign of:

A. a severe liver laceration.
B. a ruptured spleen.
C. rupture of a hollow organ.
D. intra-abdominal bleeding.
See Patient Assessment of Abdominal Injuries

Placing a pregnant patient in a supine position during the third trimester of pregnancy:

A. is recommended if the patient has severe abdominal discomfort.
B. results in spontaneous urinary incontinence if the bladder is full.
C. often causes hypotension secondary to cardiac compression.
D. might decrease the amount of blood that returns to the heart.
See Injuries of the Genitourinary System
cards.back: might decrease the amount of blood that returns to the heart.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding abdominal trauma is correct?

A. The liver is well protected and is rarely injured during a traumatic event.
B. Hollow abdominal organs are vascular and bleed profusely when injured.
C. Most of the vital abdominal organs lie within the retroperitoneal space.
D. The absence of abdominal pain does not rule out intra-abdominal bleeding.
See Anatomy and Physiology of the Abdomen
cards.back: The absence of abdominal pain does not rule out intra-abdominal bleeding.

cards.front:
Compression injuries to the abdomen that occur during a motor vehicle crash are typically the result of:

A. airbag deployment.
B. a poorly placed lap belt.
C. rapid vehicle deceleration.
D. failure to wear seat belts.
See Injuries to the Abdomen

When a hollow organ is punctured during a penetrating injury to the abdomen:

A. the abdomen will become instantly distended.
B. peritonitis might not develop for several hours.
C. it will bleed profusely and rapidly cause shock.
D. it commonly protrudes through the injury site.
See Abdominal Injuries
cards.back: peritonitis might not develop for several hours.
